bibl.title: Letter from Currier McEwen to Philip Showalter Hench, October 25, 1951

div1.p: McEwen would like to have a copy of Reed's New York University-Bellevue medical Center diploma. He provides replies to the questions Hench had posed concerning Reed's medical education and experience in New York.

div1.head: Letter from Currier McEwen to Philip Showalter Hench, October 25, 1951
div1.opener:
NEW YORK UNIVERSITY-BELLEVUE MEDICAL CENTER
NEW YORK UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF MEDICINE
477 FIRST AVENUE, NEW YORK 16, N.Y.
October 25, 1951
OFFICE OF THE DEAN
OREGON 9-3200
Dear Phil:
div1.p:
A little while ago I wrote to you concerning the mysterious dis-
appearance of the letter which you wrote to me on September 20. The
mystery has now been solved for the letter is back again on my desk hav-
ing been returned to me by Miss Helen Bayne, our librarian. I now remem-
ber, of course, that when the letter came from you I sent it up to Miss Bayne
for her comment regarding some of the questions which you asked.

Miss Bayne agrees with me that it would be very fine, indeed, if we
could have a photograph of Dr. Reed's diploma. She also provides the follow-
ing answers to your questions which I quote directly from her letter to me.

She refers me to the following book “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever”
by Howard A. Kelly, page 9....“After finishing his course at Bellevue, Dr.
Reed was attached to several of the hospitals in New York and Brooklyn,
amongst these the King's County Hospital, where he was interne. He was also
at the hospital on Randall's Island, where he went especially to study child-
ren's diseases. A little later he was appointed district physician to one
of the poorest districts in New York, and was thus brought into daily con-
tact, for the first time, with all the misery arising from poverty and vice
in a large city.”

From the book “Walter Reed Doctor in Uniform” by L.N. Wood, pages
74-75, Miss Bayne gives the following quotation: “he had taken his Bellevue
medical degree in 1872, and from that time on his services had been, for the
most part, devoted to the very poor who lived in the tenements that huddled
in side streets toward the rivers and downtown in the older parts of the city.”
On page 76...“The young doctor, while interning at the King's County Hospital
.....was appointed a Health Inspector.”

As I said at the beginning, we do not have a photograph of Reed's
diploma and we will have one more cause to be grateful to you if you will
have one made for us. I feel very foolish that I have forgotten what I had done
with your letter. It just shows how thoroughly I qualify for the role of
“absent minded professor”.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Currier McEwen, M.D.
Dean Dr. P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
